answers.answer: Sorry to hear of your concerns.  Have you considered having MRI of your brain and full spinal column?Has your physician suggested MS and/or have you raised this concern with her/him?db

Spoke with the neurosurgeon today, he said MS is possible.  I am scheduled to go to the neurologist next week for EMG and MRI ...Neurosurgeon said type II diabetes could be a concern, but I don't see how it is related ot the muscle weakness ...

I am glad that you have follow up tests scheduled.  Some of us here have had issues with MRI not being done as thoroughly as they should, and needing to have the tests repeated.  Ensure they know it is for suspected MS (the protocol is specific), preferably including the use of a contrast dye which would reveal any active lesions, if there are any.If you go the the "Health Pages" (top right corner of screen), Quix has posted some really good info on MRI's.  You might find these helpful in understanding their role in relation to diagnosing MS.I am thinking Type II diabetes could be a concern if it has caused neuropathy.  Since the various nerves innervate various muscles, this could definitely cause muscle weakness.Please keep us posted on how you make out with all of this.db

Went to the doctor today, NCV was normal, EMG was normal ...Explained the symptoms to the doctor, said I exhibited Clonus in my ankles and that MS is highly probable ...I have an MRI on the brain scheduled for Saturday, and I am effectively scared to death ...

I'm glad you have your MRI so soon, and really hope it gets you closer to some answers.I'm so sorry you are going through this.  I have been where you are, not very long ago,  and I know it is a scary and overwhelming place to be.  I do hope it is not MS, but you know, if it is, not to sound trite but it truly will not be the end of the world.Once it was finally official, I was blown away by my diagnosis (like everyone else), and was pretty much a mess emotionally.  I will say that, 7 months after being diagnosed with MS, I am doing much better.  If anyone had told me I would be doing as well as I am today, despite some symptoms that persist , I would never have believed it.  Sometimes I wonder if perhaps a part of me has still not completely grasped what has happened.  With time brings adjustment to whatever new reality you may face.  I hope it's not MS, but if it is, there are treatments to help delay the disease and treatments to help cope with symptoms, and you really can have a happy life even though that seems like an impossible idea right now.Having support makes all the difference.  Do you have friends or family members who you can confide in and who can support you through this?  And of course you always have this forum at your fingertips whenever you need it/us.If it's not MS, I hope soon they figure out what it is that's causing your symptoms, and get you on an appropriate treatment plan.Please keep us posted.  I'll be thinking of you.db
I wonder if thyroid problems would contribute to this.  An underactive thyroid would cause you to gain weight if you were female, but I'm not sure about males.
I just find it weird my doc could say > 50/50 MS with just some diffuse right-sided weakness, tingling, and a weak Clonus ... :-(

As you'll find out soon enough, doctors won't commit to a diagnosis of MS unless they're absolutely sure.  Your symptoms are neurological, but can be caused by a number of different things, like stroke, thyroid, diabetes, spinal stenosis, lyme disease, even heavy metal poisoning.

Hi, I'm sorry for the problems that are bringing you to us.  This is a scary time, and it brings up images of being crippled and not being able to live the lives we had always envisioned.  But, your doctors do not have all the answers they need yet.  They need the full MRI imaging of your brain and spine and probably some other tests like a spinal tap, a visual evoked potential VEP, and a ton of blood work to rule out mimics of MS.  This last step is very important, because there are many other diseases which can cause the things you are going through.The clonus at the ankles is the most extreme level of having hyperactive reflexes.  This indicates a spinal lesion, even if one doesn't show on the MRI, the clonus means it's there.  The weakness and tingling could be from a problem anywhere in the central nervous system.So your MRI is today.  I hope we hear from you soon about how you are doing.  IF this is MS, know that it is not a death sentence, in fact many people live very close to normal lives with the occasional obnoxious interruption.  It won't shorten your life span.  And we can help you understand what you need to.Post when you are able..Welcome again, Quix

question: Hello.  I am a 28 y/o male and definitely worried that I might have a major neurological issue.  I know that my problems don't seem to be near as problematic as some of the people posting here, but I am still concerned ...I am relatively healthy, but have gained about 60 lbs over the past 3 years and my exercise level has decreased ...About one month ago, I developed parathesias in both hands and feet, followed by muscle weakness on the right side two weeks later.  The muscle weakness is not a typical type of thing, as it like a dull aching pain in my neck, shoulder, arm, hand, and right leg.  More like a burning fatigue type sensation.  Not having any vision problems or any problems with clumsiness or decrease cognitive abilities ....I seem to be alot better at rest.  The paratheisas and pain begin when I am active in just about anyway.  Heat does not seem to make it worse.  Had an MRI done on the neck, and there were no problems.  I am really worried here ....
title: Worried abour MS :-(
